title: 107_s1868
content:
The Act is titled the "National Child Protection and Volunteers for Children Improvement Act of 2002." It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. Section 5 of the National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to define the term 'qualified State program' as policies and procedures required for implementing the Act, including timeframes for background checks, fee limits for State checks, authorized agencies, and qualified entities. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to specify the criteria for background check requests from qualified entities, including timeframes for returning results. The National Child Protection Act is being strengthened and enforced to improve background check requests for qualified entities. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow states to request background checks meeting specific guidelines for providers working with children, the elderly, or individuals with disabilities. The amendment also includes criteria for providers who are unfit due to criminal convictions or pending arrests. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow states to request background checks for providers working with vulnerable populations. The amendment sets guidelines for providers deemed unfit due to criminal history and establishes a timeframe for the Attorney General to respond to state inquiries. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow states to request national criminal background checks for providers without qualified state programs. The Attorney General must respond to requests from qualified entities within 20 business days. The Attorney General must respond to requests from qualified entities within 20 business days for national criminal background checks. Amendments allow states to request checks for providers without qualified state programs. SEC. 4. DISSEMINATION OF INFORMATION.

The National Child Protection Act of 1993 is amended to allow the Attorney General and state agencies to share criminal history background check records with qualified entities. 

SEC. 7. OFFICE FOR VOLUNTEER AND PROVIDER SCREENING.

The Attorney General will establish an Office for Volunteer and Provider Screening to facilitate national criminal background checks for care providers. Model guidelines will be provided to assist qualified entities in making fitness determinations based on criminal history records. SEC. 5. FEES.

Amends the National Child Protection Act of 1993 regarding fees for national criminal fingerprint background checks. Limits the fee for volunteers with qualified entities to $5 and for providers employed by or applying for a position with qualified entities to $18.

SEC. 6. STRENGTHENING STATE FINGERPRINT TECHNOLOGY. The Attorney General will establish a model program in each State to improve fingerprinting technology, providing funds for Live-Scan technology or electric fingerprint imaging machines. Additional funds will be given to hire personnel to train law enforcement agencies on inputting criminal data into the national background check system. The National Child Protection Act of 1993 requires states to input criminal and disposition data into the national background check system. States with a qualified program can receive up to $2,000,000 in funding. Appropriations are authorized to improve fingerprint technology and hire data entry personnel in each state and the District of Columbia from 2004 to 2008. SEC. 7. PRIVACY PROTECTIONS. Information from national criminal fingerprint background checks cannot be altered except for national security reasons. Qualified entities must designate a representative to handle requested information and delete unnecessary details. Releasing this information to unauthorized individuals carries criminal penalties. Any person who releases information from a national criminal fingerprint background check to unauthorized individuals may face a $50,000 fine or up to 1 year in prison. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for the Act includes $100,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005 through 2008. Appropriated funds will remain available until expended.
